item.title: Suez Canal: Ever Given container ship shifted from shoreline
item.description: The Ever Given has been blocking one of the world's busiest trade routes for almost a week.

item.title: Covid: Outdoor meet-ups and sports to resume in England
item.description: The stay-at-home order has ended, but people are urged to turn down hugs - even if it is "awkward".

item.title: School abuse claims could be the 'next national scandal'
item.description: A police helpline is to be set up for pupils to report complaints, following claims posted on a website.

item.title: Covid jab: One dose in care homes gives 'substantial' protection
item.description: A study suggests 62% of residents are protected by a single dose of the vaccines used in the UK.

item.title: Covid-19: 'Wedding guest list cut from 180 to 6 - but we're getting married'
item.description: With weddings back on in England, couples prepare to celebrate with their closest love ones.

item.title: George Floyd: Derek Chauvin trial begins as family demands justice
item.description: Derek Chauvin, the white policeman accused of killing George Floyd in May last year, goes on trial.

item.title: 'It's do or die time for my insurer to pay up'
item.description: Thousands of businesses across the country are feeling the pinch as insurers 'drag their heels' paying Covid claims.

item.title: Indonesia fire: Massive blaze erupts at oil refinery
item.description: Several have been injured and hundreds evacuated to safety from the blaze in West Java province.

item.title: Doctors warn against cuts to youth drug and alcohol treatment
item.description: Young people's lives are being put at risk without help for drugs and alcohol problems, they say.

item.title: Darien Gap: The 'forgotten' migrant crisis at Panama-Colombia border
item.description: It takes up to 20 days, and can be deadly – but everyday hundreds try to cross the border between Panama and Colombia.

item.title: 'Spongy roads' to be Slough's new claim to fame
item.description: Move over David Brent, settle down John Betjeman, the town is going to be an environmental pioneer.

item.title: Scottish shelters 'at capacity' with unwanted lockdown pets
item.description: The Scottish SPCA received more than 136,000 calls about unwanted animals in the past year.

item.title: Covid: Stay-at-home restrictions end in England
item.description: People in England enjoy fresh air as outdoor sport facilities reopen in lockdown easing.

item.title: The Papers: Variants warning, and 'rape culture' in schools
item.description: The easing of lockdown restrictions in England features on the front of many of Monday's papers.

item.title: 'Astronauts aren't just men - we're astronauts too'
item.description: Seven-year-old Elizabeth built her own rocket and launched it into the sky during lockdown.

item.title: Covid: The pandemic's 'dramatic' effect on cancer care
item.description: Experts predict a rise in serious cancers due to deferred screenings and treatments.

item.title: Covid: 'We need a memorial to remember'
item.description: Ellis Tustin, founder of Names not Numbers, explains why he thinks the UK needs a permanent memorial to those who have died of Covid-19.

item.title: Max Woosey tent camp-out sees 1,000 children take part
item.description: Max Woosey has raised more than £500,000 for charity by sleeping in a tent for a whole year.

item.title: ICYMI: Hotdogs, hungry horses and orange skies
item.description: See volcanic fast food and other stories in our weekly video round up: In Case You Missed It.

item.title: Congolese special effects artist behind Avengers: Endgame and Guardians of the Galaxy
item.description: Sidney Kombi Kitombo is an award-winning Congolese special effects artist behind Avengers: Endgame.

item.title: Project 17: The photograph that united a family
item.description: A photograph of a "burner boy" working on a toxic dump in Ghana helped his family to find him.

item.title: Suez Canal: How are they trying to move the Ever Given?
item.description: Significant progress has been made in efforts to fully refloat the giant cargo ship stuck in the Suez Canal since last week.

item.title: 'It is so easy to choose what voluntary work to do'
item.description: Charities are turning to technology to help them attract more volunteers.

item.title: Josh O'Connor: Romeo role 'greatest experience of my career'
item.description: The Crown star's stage role in Romeo and Juliet fizzled out - but was reborn by making a TV film.

item.title: George Floyd: When does Derek Chauvin's trial start?
item.description: A US police officer is accused of killing a black man last year. Here's why the world is watching.

item.title: The cost of the Suez Canal blockage
item.description: The blocking of the canal by the Ever Given has caused much disruption for the global shipping industry.

item.title: Easter celebrations set to rival Christmas - even down to the tree
item.description: Easter trees and garden furniture are being sought out by shoppers keen to make the most of lockdown easing.

item.title: The Netflix show putting the spotlight on menopause
item.description: The new Netflix show Bombay Begums puts the spotlight on menopause, but why aren't we talking about it?

item.title: Not just the Proms: An unexpected history of the Royal Albert Hall
item.description: Rule Britannia has had its place - but so have Bovril, balls, Blackshirts and a bombastic celebration of the Bard.

item.title: Boat Race 2021: Famous duel returns to quiet backwater
item.description: The famous duel will take place on the Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire for the first time since 1944.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: Black Power: A British story of resistance told through music
item.description: This time, the revolution is being televised, but it was music that gave Black Power a timeless platform.

item.title: 'My pet has helped me so much during the pandemic'
item.description: Research has shown pets can have a huge benefit to our mental health - especially this past year.

item.title: 'Impact player' Curran will get better and better - Buttler
item.description: All-rounder Sam Curran will get "better and better", according to stand-in England captain Jos Buttler.

item.title: 'Now Tuchel picks him everyone will agree' - how 'exceptional' Mount is proving critics wrong
item.description: Four months after receiving social media abuse, Mason Mount strengthens his case to become a regular in Gareth Southgate's England team with another strong performance against Albania.

item.title: Fraser strike nets Scotland point in Israel
item.description: Ryan Fraser's deft finish earns Scotland a point as they fight back in their second World Cup qualifier against Israel in Tel Aviv.

item.title: England's Euro U21 hopes hang by a thread after Portugal loss
item.description: England chances of reaching the Euro Under-21 Championship quarter-finals hang by a thread following a limp display and defeat to Portugal.

item.title: Robertson beats O'Sullivan to win Tour Championship
item.description: Neil Robertson claims the Tour Championship with a 10-4 win as Ronnie O'Sullivan suffers his fifth ranking final defeat of the season.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms, pubs and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid passports: What are different countries planning?
item.description: How advanced are some countries' plans for vaccine certificates and Covid passports?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 29 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid rules: What is the rule of six in England?
item.description: The rule of six is back for England from Monday but with some changes - we explain what they are.

item.title: Does the Oxford vaccine have a blood clot problem? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: India coronavirus: Why have vaccine exports been suspended?
item.description: India is a big player in vaccine production - but companies are warning of supply problems.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
